titlestmt.titleproper: Library Company of Philadelphia miscellaneous manuscripts collection 1846-1999
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection-level EAD record is a product of the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL) Consortial Survey Initiative, which was funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid generated in EAD from data in the PACSCL Consortial Survey Database on 12/21/2012

did.unittitle: Library Company of Philadelphia miscellaneous manuscripts collection

bioghist.p: The Library Company of Philadelphia is an independent research library concentrating on American society and culture from the 17th through 19th centuries. It was founded in 1731 by Benjamin Franklin as a subscription library supported by its shareholders, as it is to this day. Free and open to the public, the Library Company houses an extensive non-circulating collection of rare books, manuscripts, broadsides, ephemera, and works of art.

scopecontent.p: This is a small collection of miscellaneous manuscript and printed ephemera dating from 1846 to 1898. Items include: receipts, many with the names Isaac L. Williams and Anna E. Williams; bill heads and blank bank drafts; correspondence, including a 1849 letter to Jane Strickland from J. Bremenhall and several manuscript pages regarding the Bank of the U.S. (with a transcription of the pages); fragments of printed volumes, including several pages of a German humor magazine, poems, and almanac pages; and commencement programs, concert programs, and other announcements from Ingham University (1885-87). The collection also includes a brochure about the 1999 Connecticut Charter Oak Quarter (with a quarter attached).

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
